title: Lexeme
description: A lexeme is used broadly by DLx to refer to any collection of related senses and forms, whether the item is an individual word, a construction, a morpheme, or even a fully-inflected phrase. In other words, DLx lexeme objects can be used to describe anything that constitutes a lexical unit or memorized chunk. A lexeme will often have multiple *senses* or meanings, and those are listed in the `senses` field. It is up to the linguist to decide when two meanings are related, and therefore part of the same lexeme, or when they belong in different lexemes. A lexeme will also often have multiple forms, even before considering inflection. For example, the lexeme `run` in English has two base forms: `run` and `ran`. These different base forms of a lexeme are listed in the `forms` field. The `baseForms` field should *not* be used to list all the inflectional forms of a lexeme. NB: An entry in a dictionary does *not* represent a lexeme, but rather a lexeme form (see the `forms` attribute instead).

citationForm.title: Citation Form
citationForm.description: The citation form of a lexeme is the form given in isolation, which may be different from its lemma form. For example, in English the citation form of a verb is typically the infinitive, e.g. `to run`, even though `run` is typically used as its lemma form. It may be represented in multiple orthographies.

examples.title: Examples
examples.description: A collection of examples illustrating this lexeme in use. Each example is a phrase from a text.

forms.title: Forms
forms.description: The different base forms that this lexeme has, other than its lemma form. These are usually suppletive forms of a root or stem, e.g. `ran` as the past form of `run`, or `men` as the plural form of `man`. A lexeme form is generally what is listed as an entry in the dictionary. In the usual scenario, the main entry is listed under the lemma form, and contains detailed information about the lexeme, while entries for each of the different lexeme forms are simply pointers to the main entry. If the lemma has allomorphs, you should list the lemma form again here.

items.title: Lexeme Form
items.description: One of the forms of a lexeme.

allomorphs.title: Allomorphs
allomorphs.description: A list of allomorphs of this form.

transcription.title: Transcription
transcription.description: A transcription of this allomorph, optionally in multiple orthographies.

environments.title: Environments
environments.description: A list of (morpho)phonological environments in which this allomorph occurs.

items.title: Environment
items.description: A formalization of a (morpho)phonologial environemnt, e.g. `_k`.

components.title: Components
components.description: A list of the forms contained within the current form. For example, the form `gentlemen` in an English lexicon might have references to the form `gentle`, and the form `men` within the lexeme for `man`. Components may reference either an entire lexeme or a specific lexeme form.

examples.title: Examples
examples.description: A collection of examples illustrating this form in use. Each example is a phrase.

form.title: Transcription
form.description: A transcription of this lexeme form, optionally in multiple orthographies.

headword.title: Headword
headword.description: The dictionary headword that this form should be found under, optionally in multiple orthographies. If the `headword` attribute is missing or empty, programs should use the citation form for the headword, if present. Otherwise, the lemma form should be used.

notes.title: Notes
notes.description: A collection of notes about this lexeme form.

references.title: Bibliographic References
references.description: A collection of bibliographic references about this lexeme form, if it has been discussed in the literature.

syllableStructure.title: Syllable Structure
syllableStructure.description: An abstract representation of the syllable structure of this form, e.g. `CVC`.

tone.title: Tone
tone.description: An abstract representation of the tonal pattern of this lexeme form. Examples: `HLH`, `323`, etc.

transcription.title: Transcription
transcription.description: A transcription of this lexeme form, optionally in multiple orthographies.

type.title: Lexeme Form Type
type.description: The type of lexeme form, identifying when this form of the lexeme is used. Values might be `past`, `plural`, `phrase-final`, etc.

variantOf.title: Variant Of
variantOf.description: When this lexeme form is a variant of another lexeme form, this field will contain a reference to the other lexeme. Lexeme forms may only be variants of one other lexeme form.

key.title: Lexeme Key
key.description: A human-readable key that helps uniquely identify this lexeme within its lexicon. Best practice is for the key to consist of the lemma form of the word in the default orthography, and if the word is a homonym, the homonym number. However, any value is acceptable as long as it is unique within the lexicon. (Keys do not need to be unique across lexicons.)

lemma.title: Lemma
lemma.description: The lemma form of this lexeme. In the DLx framework, a lemma is an abstract form meant to represent the lexeme. It may differ drastically from the citation form or headword form. For example, the form `be` is typically used as the lemma form of the English verb `to be` (which would be its citation form). Lemmas may be represented in multiple orthographies.

lexicalRelations.title: Lexical Relations
lexicalRelations.description: A list of the lexical relations that this lexeme has to other lexemes.

literalMeaning.title: Literal Meaning
literalMeaning.description: The literal meaning of the lexeme, optionally in multiple orthographies.

morphemeType.title: Morpheme Type
morphemeType.description: The type of morpheme or complex construction that this lexeme is. Examples: `root`, `stem`, `bipartite stem`, `enclitic`, `prefix`, `inflected word`, `phrase`, `circumfix`

notes.title: Notes
notes.description: A collection of notes about this lexeme.

references.title: References
references.description: A collection of bibliographic references relating to this lexeme. For example, a particular lexeme may have been discussed in detail in a published article.

senses.title: Senses
senses.description: A collection of senses for this lexeme.

items.title: Sense
items.description: One of the meanings for this lexeme. Every lexeme must have at least 1 sense.

argumentStructure.title: Argument Structure
argumentStructure.description: An abstract representation of the argument structure for this word.

category.title: Lexical Category (Part of Speech, Morphosyntactic Class, etc.)
category.description: The lexical category, part of speech, or morphosyntactic class for this lexeme. If the current lexeme is an affix or other grammatical (rather than lexical) morpheme, this field should be used to describe the category that the morpheme attaches to. Examples: the English verb suffix `‑s` would set this property to `verb`, and the English derivational suffix `‑ize` would set this property to `noun`.

definition.title: Definition
definition.description: The definition for this particular sense, optionally in multiple orthographies.

derives.title: Derived Category
derives.description: If this lexeme is a derivational morpheme, this field indicates the type of lexical category, part of speech, or morphosyntactic class that is derived when this morpheme is applied. For example, the English derivational suffix `‑er` would have this property set to `noun`.

examples.title: Examples
examples.description: A collection of examples of this sense in use. Each example is a phrase.

gloss.title: Gloss
gloss.description: A short version of the definition, using Leipzig-style glossing notation.

inflectionClass.title: Inflectional Class
inflectionClass.description: If this lexeme is a root or stem, this field indicates the inflectional class that the lexeme takes. If this lexeme is an inflectional morpheme, this field indicates the inflectional class that the morpheme belongs to. If this lexeme is a derivational morpheme, this field indicates the inflectional class of the derived form.

lexicalRelations.title: Lexical Relations
lexicalRelations.description: A collection of lexical relations between this sense and other senses in this lexicon or other lexicons.

notes.title: Notes
notes.description: A collection of notes about this sense.

references.title: Bibliographic References
references.description: A collection of bibliographic references about this particular sense.

scientificName.title: Scientific Name
scientificName.description: The scientific name for this item.

usages.title: Usages
usages.description: A list of the appropriate usages for this sense. Example: `formal`, `medicinal`, `informal`, etc.

variantOf.title: Variant Of
variantOf.description: If this sense is a variant of another sense, a reference to the other sense should go here. An example use case might be if one speaker uses a word to mean one sense, and another speaker uses the same word to mean another thing.

variantOf.title: Variant Of
variantOf.description: When this lexeme is a variant of another lexeme, this field should contain a reference to the other lexeme. Lexemes may only be variants of one other lexeme.

includedIn.title: Included In
includedIn.description: A list of references to lexemes or lexeme forms that this item is included in. For example, the lexeme `‑s` (English plural for nouns) would have a reference to the lexeme `pants`, among others.

lexicalRelation.description: A lexical relation between two lexemes or senses.

relation.title: Lexical Relation Type
relation.description: The type of lexical relation that holds between the current lexeme and the referenced lexeme. Can also be used for general cross-references (a `compare` relation) or historical relationships (a `derivedFrom` or `originOf` relation). Examples: `antonym`, `synonym`, `cognate`, `derivedFrom`, `originOf`, `compare`, `partOf`, `hypernymOf`, `hyponymOf`.

source.title: Source
source.description: The source(s) of information about this lexeme. This will often be the initials of a speaker.

variants.title: Variants
variants.description: A collection of variants of this lexeme / lexeme form / sense.

items.title: Variant
items.description: A reference to, and information about, a variant of the current lexeme / lexeme form / sense.

variantType.title: Variant Type
variantType.description: The type of variant that this item is. Possible values might be a person's name (representing an idiolectal variant), or simply `idiolectal`, or `dialectal` (or the name of the dialect), or `rapid speech`, etc.
